div1.p: Reed congratulates Kean on his promotion to Colonel. [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia Library]

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Jefferson Randolph Kean, February 23, 1899
div1.opener:
How about
that V? Have
you put it on
yet?--
WAR DEPARTMENT,
SURGEON GENERAL'S OFFICE,
ARMY MEDICAL MUSEUM AND LIBRARY,
WASHINGTON.
Feb. 23. '99
My dear Colonel:
div1.p:
Have just
seen your promotion in
the Post. Allow me to ex=
tend to you & dear Mrs.
Kean my sincerist con=
gratulations on the high
honor conferred upon
you - I am confident
that you fully deserved
it - I would be willing
to run up against you
nowagain, even though you are
my superior officer -
Of course, you would nat-
urally be a little reserved
& dignified, at first; but
a few “toddies” would
bring you around alright
I feel sure! Well, by
Jove! good luck to
you, old man! Go right
ahead after Leonard
Wood! I shouldn't be
surprised to see you
a Brigadier yet! Your past good
work deserves it all.

With love to Mrs. Kean
and dear little Martha, I am,
div1.closer:
Your sincere friend, Walter Reed. Colonel Jeff. R. Kean, U.S.A.
Havana, Cuba.
